ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basic principles of microeconomics and how to apply those principles to questions on economic decisions and behavior.
I learned about the basics of microeconomics, such as indifference curves, finding the optimal bundle, profit maximization, and different economic models.

Broad understanding of concepts relating to microeconomics including analyzing supply and demand curves, marginal products, and different market structure's approaches to the production and the labor market.
Basic econ combined with Tolgas life lessons
A solid overview of introductory microeconomics.
I learned a few economic formulas and a couple econ concepts. I especially liked the interdisciplinary pieces where I saw clearly how our learning connected to my life.

This course gave a solid introduction to the study of microeconomics. The economic principles that were taught are useful in thinking about everyday life and give a good foundation for future econ classes.
This course teaches of the foundations of microeconomics and provides a comprehensive account of the basic components of the economic system.
Foundational aspects of microecon.
I learned about economics on a global and local scale, as well as how to interpret it conceptually and mathematically
I got a better understand of consumer and producer behavior. And a better understanding of the basic principles of economics. I also developed my problem solving and critical thinking skills.
I learned a good overview of microeconomics and developed the tools for thinking about economics overall.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Tolga is a really engaging professor, and the peer tutors are great.
I liked the small size of the class because it made it easier to ask questions during class and get to know the professor. I think the class could be improved by having more student participation.

The strength of this class is the small class size. It truly allows for smaller questions that may not be asked in lecture to be answered and discussed in detail. The main weakness is the ability for one or two people to break the curve significantly more because of the smaller distribution.
Amazing professor. Great textbook. There could be more problem sets to practice for the exam. Sometimes the professor rushes way too much with numerical examples and computations.

The weakness of the course, to me, was that the material seemed a little too simplistic and impractical - for instance, the formulas we learned would never actually work in real life. But I felt Tolga did as good a job as he possibly could have.

The seminar style of this course encourages more engagement, and because of this, it is much easier to absorb the material. The limited number of assessments means that you are responsible for staying on top of your work, and this means the exams and problem sets carry a lot of weight.

This is a very rich and providing lecture class, in which students are constantly encouraged to understand the daily applications of economic theories. At the same time, the content comes primarily through these (often extremely fast-paced) lectures. A stronger use of the textbook and additional resources would stand to make the course more functional.

As somebody who works better with practice problems, I felt as though I did not receive enough practice problems to fully learn the content. We were merely told to go to class and read the book, but that didn't help me fully grasp my learning.

It was a great class and I love how the professor made the class more interesting through comedic engagement. However, the class moved very fast at times. During class wed move very fast and take intermittent breaks. If we room fewer breaks maybe we could have moved through the material slower while covering the same amount of material.
Strengths: The lectures in this course were very well organized. Weaknesses: the material sometimes felt rushed and difficult to understand, and there weren't enough practice problems.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Micro is great, especially if you have Tolga. Office hours are really helpful if you're struggling with anything. Tolga's lectures are really fun.
Yes, I loved this class!
Absolutely. Tolga was a great teacher and a very entertaining person. I strongly suggest taking this class with Tolga Koker specifically.
I took this class Credit/D/Fail and really enjoyed it. The curve is strict so dont go into it expecting an A.
If you're an ECON major, definitely take it. If not, consider credit/d/fail it.
If they want to study economics, its a reasonable place to start, and I certainly love Tolga, so that is a big plus for the class.
Yes. If you are considering studying econ I would recommend this course over the lecture. It is more engaging, and class is enjoyable.
I would recommend this course to a student interested in the foundations of microeconomics who is willing to sort for themselves a stronger sense of the material given the content provided.
Not unless you had to take it as a requirement or prereq.
If you have taken AP Econ before, then definitely take this class. However, if you have no economics background, this WILL be a challenging class
I would because its very interesting material and its helpful to know these principles.

While I would recommend taking intro microeconomics, I would recommend thinking carefully about taking the seminar section. Your understanding of microeconomics all depends on how the material is taught, so it might be worth considering both this and the big lecture.
